H0.text: The presence of dark matter is evidence that the universe is expanding.

H1.text: Red shift of light from distant galaxies is evidence that the universe is expanding.

H2.text: Constant speed of light from every perspective is evidence that the universe is expanding.

H3.text: Emission of high-energy gamma rays by distant objects is evidence that the universe is expanding.

A4.text: The observations of increasing redshifts from more and more distant galaxies can be modelled assuming a homogeneous and isotropic universe combined with general relativity.

A5.text: The largest-observed redshift, corresponding to the greatest distance and furthest back in time, is that of the cosmic microwave background radiation; the numerical value of its redshift is about z = 1089 (z = 0 corresponds to present time), and it shows the state of the universe about 13.8 billion years ago, and 379,000 years after the initial moments of the Big Bang.
